Alas. I've read/listened to as much of The Alchemist as I'm going to read/listen to. There is probably about 20% left and I just...can't. I tried. But I can't. I can't say it was the audio reader. She wasn't too bad. It was just..was it me? Or was it the book. This is a book that I've heard either people love it or they hate it. In my opinion, I'd say it ground on my nerves. I like books with meaning but if I want parables that I need to study and decipher I'll read the Bible. This is a work of fiction which I am reading in my leisure. Why do I need a secret decoder ring. I don't like books want me to do this. I don't like books that are so steeped in symbols that it's not enjoyable to me. Okay, I get it. Paul Coelho was trying to be all deep and talk about the meaning of life and goals and purpose and all that jazz but it just annoyed me. The story annoyed me. Where in the world was the plot? It seemed that Paul wanted to philosophize and just tried to create a story around his knowledge dropping. Even though I get what he was trying to say and I do agree, from what I understood. I still didn't dig it. Am I a member of the left hand mass of those who hate this book? I wouldn't say I hated it but it did really grind my gears. This is my second Paul Coelho book. I tried By The River Piedra I Sat Down and Welp and I didn't care for it either. It was another book that I felt the author used to push more of his religious beliefs and philosophical rationalizations off on us the reader. I technically think he should call it non-fiction and say, here's an analogy to explain what I mean about this belief of mine. Because to me.. that is what it is. That being said, I tried and I think I'm finished with Paul Coelho books. Talented? Yes. But, not enjoyable to me. I have got to go with the two stars. It was just everywhere but somewhere that kept my focus. I really couldn't even tell you what the story was about but I can tell you the philosophy. Smh! See, that's my point. No recommend or discourage. To each his/her own. You might like it. It was not for she.

Audiobook performed by Jeremy IronsThis is Coehlo’s international best-selling classic tale of an Andalusian shepherd boy’s quest to find his own Personal Legend. Santiago is tending his sheep when he is puzzled by a recurring dream in which a boy says that there is hidden treasure at the Pyramids in Egypt. A gypsy woman offers to interpret the dream in exchange for a promise of one tenth the treasure. Santiago agrees, but feels no closer to a solution. The next day he encounters an old man, who says he is king of Salem, and tells him he must seek his own Personal Legend. And thus Santiago’s quest begins. On his travels he also meets a thief, a crystal merchant, an alchemist, a desert woman, tribal chieftains, and a caravan leader, all of whom help – in some fashion or other – Santiago on his quest. But his ultimate discovery is that one’s treasure lies close to home.This fable has captured the attention and imagination of a worldwide readership. And the story of how it came to be published, somewhat parallels the story told. The message is simplistic, even as the images are somewhat unrealistic, even fantastic. I can see why it became such a gigantic hit – it’s an allegorical fable about finding one’s true self, wrapped in an adventure and with a little romantic interest added for good measure, but it really didn’t do too much for me. I found it entertaining but not particularly inspiring. Jeremy Irons does a magnificent job performing the audio version. He is a great actor and gives life to these characters. From the innocent boy, to the Crystal merchant and the Alchemist, each character comes to life with his performance. Irons’s performance was mesmerizing and engaging, but at the end I felt as if I had missed something. I think that is the fault of Coelho’s writing, though, not the narrator’s performance. I would rate the audio performance 5 stars.

The Alchemist is much more then just an adventure book. Santiagos journey is about following your heart and not giving up on your dreams. “The secret of happiness is to see all the marvels of the world, and never to forget the drops of oil on the spoon.”

I gave this book 4 stars, because it is everything it sets out to be. You could say that it appeals to the big and pompous part of me that is probably naive and foolish, because sometimes I want to believe that I can turn stones into gold, and can command the Universe to do my bidding. As a teenager I am sure I would have loved it (Hey, I also believed Dr Seuss when he said my success was 98 and 3/4 % guaranteed). As a woman in her thirties (when I read it) I still enjoyed it for the storytelling and the call to follow our dreams (sometimes we all need a little nudging). It *is* quite simplistic, but it's told from the perspective of a simple shepherd boy with stars in his eyes who sets off to follow his dreams, explore more of the world and find his place in it. The writing was easy to follow and engaging.

”Where your treasure is, there also will be your heart.”It's a fable. A parable. An allegory. It's almost an interesting bedtime story, but it's far too long for what it accomplishes. Yes, it's about the journey, I got it...but I wanted something more to happen. This is where the book is simply a fable too long for its story. I'd rather this had been whittled down into a short story within a collection. Or perhaps broken up into four shorter stories within a collection that also included other stories that take place outside this boy's world—for cushioning.Audiobook, as narrated by Jeremy Irons: Thank goodness this short book had the steady, reliable voice of a known actor handling the narration. Otherwise I might not have even finished it. Jeremy Irons did great. (Although the Sun (I believe it was) sounded an awful lot like Dudley Moore.)
